key_points: U.S. intelligence agencies predicted an attack outside Kabul airport, leading to a State Department warning.
A suicide bomber killed at least 13 U.S. service members and 79 Afghans outside Kabul airport.
The attack marked the largest loss of U.S. military life in Afghanistan in a decade, occurring amid troop withdrawal.
Questions arise about security measures and why U.S. troops were concentrated in one area despite warnings.
General Frank McKenzie acknowledged a failure in security but noted the necessity of screening evacuees.
Officials claim delays in evacuating at-risk Afghans were due to slow processing and challenges in securing third-country housing.
Criticism targets President Biden's decision to return Bagram airbase, with some arguing it could have facilitated a more orderly evacuation.
The Pentagon is focused on withdrawing the remaining 5,000 troops, with the next few days expected to be extremely dangerous.
The U.S. launched a drone strike against an ISIS-K attack planner in retaliation for the airport attack.
Officials acknowledge challenges in degrading ISIS-K's capabilities despite efforts since 2014.
spokespersons: General Frank McKenzie (head of U.S. Central Command)
